descript.abstract: Layer identifies the location of cell phone towers throughout Grenada. The location data was obtained from The National Telecom Regulatory Commission (Grenada). GPS position of cell sites was received in an excel file. Using ExpertGPS software, the positions were converted to a shapefile. Location data represents the two telecom providers operating in Grenada, Digicel Grenada Ltd and Lime Grenada. Attempts were made to obtain carrying capacity of individual towers from operators however, it was unsuccessful. These were marked with a "-9999" value.
descript.purpose: Resource developed to locate and document capacity of cell phone towers. This information will help inform The Nature Conservancy's AWE project. Scientists around the world agree that climate change is indisputable. Impacts, including rising sea levels, increased storm intensity, warming temperatures and acidifying waters, dying coral reefs, shifting fish stocks, and incidence of flooding and drought, are already being felt, and are expected to continue and increase for decades to come. Nature holds some of the world’s best and most practical solutions to climate change, solutions that keep nature and people healthy, safe, and secure. The goal of At the Water’s Edge (AWE) is to demonstrate that governments and people in vulnerable coastal communities in Grenada and St. Vincent and the Grenadines (SVG) can enhance their resilience to climate change by protecting, restoring and effectively managing their marine and coastal ecosystems (also known as ecosystem-based adaptation or EBA) and strengthening local capacity for adaptation.
